entry.title: Combined summary - Trying all address types in message signing verification (BIP)
entry.summary: Ali Sherief proposed a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) to address the lack of standardization for Segwit message signatures. While it is technically possible to sign and verify segwit addresses, conventional tools only attempt to reconstruct a legacy address, resulting in wallets inserting the segwit address into the address field instead. The proposed BIP aims to standardize the practice of placing the segwit address into the address field without altering the message signing format. The verification procedure will try different address hashing algorithms in sequence to reconstruct the address in the signed message. In the signing process, the only modification is the insertion of the Segwit address in place of the legacy address. The proposal does not replace, supersede, or obsolete existing BIPs and only sets guidelines for writing a message signing and verification procedure. It was noted that COLDCARD makes signatures exactly like that when told to sign with a segwit address, using Sparrow to verify this signature. However, there are no known "verifiers" that will accept the signature provided by Peter (Coinkite Inc). Lastly, it was mentioned that there is no BIP for the original signing method, as it was directly from Satoshi himself when the original client was written.In order to address the lack of standardization for Segwit message signatures, Ali Sherief proposed a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) that would set guidelines for writing a message signing and verification procedure. Currently, wallets that support signing and verifying a bitcoin message can only sign legacy addresses, and although it is technically possible to sign and verify segwit addresses, there is no widely accepted standard for doing so. The proposal aims to standardize the practice of placing the segwit address into the address field, without requiring alterations to the message signing format like those in BIPs 173 or 322.The BIP does not replace, supersede, or obsolete any existing BIPs, but rather proposes a sequence of address hashing algorithms to reconstruct the address in the signed message during the verification process. These include P2PKH (legacy address), P2WPKH-P2SH (nested segwit), and P2WPKH with version from 0 to MAX_WITNESS_VERSION. In the signing procedure, the only modification is the insertion of the segwit address in place of the legacy address in the signed message. If approved, this BIP does not require any changes to existing signed messages, and the original sign/verify algorithms will continue to interoperate with this improved sign/verify algorithm, without any action necessary from the developers.Peter from Coinkite Inc mentioned that the BIP-322 proposals did not gain wide acceptance in the past, but there is renewed interest in using it to validate signatures related to upgrading the Bitcoin-native Decentralized Identifier Method (did:btcr) beyond its current specification, to version 2.0. Craig Raw verifies the signature by converting the message and signature to a public key, trying first BIP137 and then the approach used by Electrum. The script type is extracted from the provided address and compared against the address constructed with the public key using the same script type.Ali Sherief believes that a "defacto" BIP is needed and useful to do, and then Core should be updated to support it as well. There is no need for any auxiliary feature additions into this BIP, and the original approach was directly from Satoshi himself when the original client was written. It has never been codified in a BIP as far as he knows. There is also discussion about the "ascii armor" that is sometimes used, where newline-treatment isn't defined well enough for good interoperability. Overall, the proposed BIP aims to standardize the practice of placing the segwit address into the address field without requiring alterations to the message signing format, improving the security and privacy in the handling of decentralized identifiers on the Bitcoin blockchain.Based on personal experience, it is possible to gain a wealth of knowledge and valuable insights.
